urn:contentItem:5XM2-HFJ1-F12F-F3N1-00000-00SEN. CANTWELL, SENATE DEMOCRATS UNVEIL STRONG ONLINE PRIVACY RIGHTS2019-11-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:06ZLexisNexisSEN. CANTWELL, SENATE DEMOCRATS UNVEIL STRONG ONLINE PRIVACY RIGHTS

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The office of Sen. Maria Cantwell issued the following press release:

Today U.S. Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation Ranking Member Maria Cantwell (D-WA) and fellow senior members Senators Brian Schatz (D-HI), Amy Klobuchar (D-MN), and Ed Markey (D-MA) unveiled comprehensive federal online privacy legislation to establish privacy rights, outlaw harmful and deceptive practices, and improve data security safeguards for the record number of American consumers who now shop or conduct business online.

With new numbers showing that nearly sixty percent of all holiday spending will be done online-making this the largest online holiday shopping season ever -families everywhere want strong action taken to protect their online privacy and data security. Says former Director of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection and Georgetown Law Professor David Vladeck: "The bill not only codifies privacy as a right -a measure long overdue -but it also recognizes that 'rights' that are unenforceable are empty gestures. For that reason, the bill not only restores control of personal information to consumers, but equally important, the bill gives consumers and the Federal Trade Commission real tools to hold companies accountable when they collect information without permission, when they fail to reasonably safeguard consumers' information, or when they misuse that information."

The Consumer Online Privacy Rights Act (COPRA) gives Americans control over their personal data; prohibits companies from using consumers' data to harm or deceive them; establishes strict standards for the collection, use, sharing, and protection of consumer data; protects civil rights; and penalizes companies that fail to meet data protection standards. The legislation also codifies the rights of individuals to pursue claims against entities that violate their data privacy rights.

"In the growing online world, consumers deserve two things: privacy rights and a strong law to enforce them," Ranking Member Cantwell said. "They should be like your Miranda rights-clear as a bell as to what they are and what constitutes a violation."

"When consumers let companies use their personal information they should be able to trust that it will be protected and won't be used to harm them," said Senator Schatz. "Our bill lays out a set of strong data privacy rights for consumers, establishes robust obligations for companies, and gives prosecutors and consumers the tools they need to hold big tech companies accountable."

"Companies continue to profit off of the personal data they collect from Americans, but they leave consumers completely in the dark about how their personal information is being used. Consumers have a right to know if their personal data is being sold and to easily see what data has already been distributed," said Senator Klobuchar. "Our legislation establishes digital rules of the road for companies, ensures that consumers have the right to access and control how their personal data is being used, and gives the Federal Trade Commission and state attorneys general the tools they need to hold big tech companies accountable. It's time for Congress to pass comprehensive privacy legislation."

"The demand for consumers' personal information today is at an all-time high," Senator Markey said. "But while the appetite for our data has skyrocketed in recent years, Americans have not yet been given a set of strong, enforceable rights that protect us from privacy invasions. This bill gives consumers strong privacy protections, including prohibitions on harmful discriminatory uses of our data and strict data security requirements. I look forward to working with my colleagues on the Senate Commerce Committee to enact a comprehensive federal privacy bill, which must include heightened protections for vulnerable populations, like children and teens."

This bill tackles teen privacy with new safeguards, recognizing the need to do more to protect children and young people's online privacy-a challenge that Senator Markey has been working hard to address and that should be included in comprehensive privacy legislation.

The full text of the Consumer Online Privacy Rights Act (COPRA) can be found HERE: https://www.cantwell.senate.gov/download/copra-bill-text

A one-pager on the legislation can be found HERE: https://www.cantwell.senate.gov/download/copra-one-pager

The just-released Commerce Committee report titled The State of Online Privacy and Data Security can be found HERE: https://www.cantwell.senate.gov/download/the-state-of-online-privacy-and-data-security

Consumer and civil rights advocates and privacy experts support the legislation:

Georgetown University Law Center Professor David Vladeck: "This bill marks an important step forward for Congress. The bill gives consumers the right to regain control of their personal information -whether it is collected, and how it may be used. The bill not only codifies privacy as a right -a measure long overdue -but it also recognizes that 'rights' that are unenforceable are empty gestures. For that reason, the bill not only restores control of personal information to consumers, but equally important, the bill gives consumers and the Federal Trade Commission real tools to hold companies accountable when they collect information without permission, when they fail to reasonably safeguard consumers' information, or when they misuse that information. And the bill is careful to recognize that federal law can coexist with state privacy laws. Kudos to the bill's sponsors for their willingness to take on the internet giants, put the brakes on the indiscriminate and ubiquitous data collection and restore the ability of consumers to control their personal data." Former FTC Commissioner

Justin Brookman, Director of Privacy and Technology Policy at Consumer Reports: "This is strong legislation that directly goes after companies that build secret profiles about what we do online and off. We appreciate the bill sponsors' leadership on data privacy, and we look forward to working with Congress to finally pass legislation to protect our personal information. This bill is an important step toward treating privacy as a fundamental right for all Americans."

University of Washington Law School Professor Ryan Calo: "This legislation represents a sea change, particularly in the way federal law thinks about privacy harm. As the bill makes abundantly clear, violating the privacy rights and expectations of consumers is harmful in and of itself, a harm that must be redressed by regulators and courts. Such a statement by Congress is sorely needed and will have a big impact on consumer privacy in America."

Georgetown Law Center on Privacy & Technology Executive Director Laura Moy: "For years, Americans have been clamoring for privacy-not just for incremental improvement, but for a transformative shift that will finally restore some sense of control to 21st century consumers. The Consumer Data Rights Act answers that call. It gives consumers meaningful rights and establishes robust enforcement mechanisms that will incentivize companies to comply. Just as important, this legislation directly addresses harmful uses of data, including discrimination. I applaud this bill and wholeheartedly hope to see it pass."

Marc Morial, President and CEO of the National Urban League: "African Americans and people of color are over indexed as consumers of traditional and social media. As such, our data are uniquely vulnerable to exploitation, including civil liberties abuse, targeted disinformation campaigns designed to suppress the vote, and exclusion from employment, health, educational, and housing opportunities. I commend the bill sponsors for their leadership and on including important protections for civil and human rights in the Consumer Online Privacy Rights Act. This legislation is an important first step. In the 21st century, privacy legislation must ensure data cannot be used in ways to undermine hard-fought civil rights. We look forward to working with House and Senate leadership on comprehensive data privacy rights legislation."

The Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law: "In today's online economy, we have seen how the misuse of personal data can exacerbate discrimination in housing, employment, credit, and education. The Consumer Online Privacy Rights Act prioritizes civil rights by ensuring that individuals' personal data cannot be used for discriminatory purposes and that big data algorithms are assessed for bias."

Electronic Privacy Information Center (EPIC) Policy Director Caitriona Fitzgerald: "The Consumer Online Privacy Rights Act (COPRA) is outstanding. The Consumer Online Privacy Rights Act gives consumers meaningful rights, holds companies accountable, and protects stronger state safeguards. EPIC reviewed the bills pending in Congress and has now given the Consumer Data Rights Act an A-. With the addition of a data protection agency, the bill would earn an A and establish a comprehensive approach for privacy protection for the U.S."

Federal Consumer Programs U.S. PIRG (and WashPIRG) Senior Director Edmund Mierzwinski: "This strong privacy bill implements, among others, several principles any federal privacy bill must start with and then build onto. First, it grants consumers strong, enforceable rights against all privacy harms, explicitly including a violation of the act's provisions. Second, it preserves stronger state laws and the right of the states to innovate."

Mr. Hilary O. Shelton, Director of the NAACP Washington Bureau and Senior Vice President for Policy and Advocacy: "Research demonstrates that African Americans use social media at a disproportionately high rate; thus the NAACP is deeply appreciative of efforts to preserve the privacy of our data and to stop disinformation campaigns which may suppress and / or diffuse our voting power or limit our health, education, and employment opportunities to name a few. We look forward to working with the Ranking Member and the other sponsors of this important legislation whose intent is to protect our civil rights and civil liberties, and to protect our most basic personal information."

Ranking Member Cantwell has long been a leading advocate for online protections for American consumers. As Congress has worked to develop privacy legislation, she has repeatedly called for comprehensive privacy protections. She has led the fight to protect and restore net neutrality rules to keep a free and open internet. She has also championed the importance of investing in cybersecurity measures throughout the U.S. economy and pushed federal agencies like the FTC to take a more robust role in protecting Americans from privacy threats. Chuck Schumer (D-NY) Makes Weekend Trip To Examine Border Conditions; Equifax Reaches $575M Settlement in 2017 Data Breach; Crisis At The Border2019-07-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:06ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMichael Block, Mitch Roschelle, Lee Carter, Ron Vitiello, Liz Young, KT Guttenberg, Josh BoudreauxNEWSFinancial072203cb.231Sen. Chuck Schumer (D-NY) Makes Weekend Trip To Examine Border Conditions; Equifax Reaches $575M Settlement in 2017 Data Breach; Crisis At The BorderCheryl Casone, Dagen Mcdowell, Blake Burman, Kristina Partsinevelos, Stuart Varney, Jeff Flock

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 22nd. Your top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern, another big week of earnings, the biggest week including tech names, Facebook, Twitter, and Google's parent Alphabet all reporting. We've got 10 of the 30 Dow Components out with quarterly results this week. Halliburton out earlier with a beat on earnings, a miss on revenue, and the stock flat. The company did say momentum is building internationally. Futures are showing gains across the board, a 58-point gain on the Dow Futures, the S&P and NASDAQ up as well, this after a losing week for the three major market gauges here in the U.S., the first down week in three.

Check on global market action, in Europe, we have gains across the board, up about a quarter of one percent, a third of a percent gain on the FTSE- 100 in England. In Asia overnight, it was red across the board in Japan, Shanghai, Hong Kong, and South Korea. Growing tensions with Iran, Prime Minister Theresa May holding an emergency meeting following the seizure of a U.K. tanker by Iran's revolutionary guard. Meantime, Iran reportedly detaining 17 of its own citizens accused of acting as spies for the CIA. Reaction from the Trump Administration later this hour.

The border battle, President Donald Trump extending an invitation to Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer following his trip to the southern border. The President saying a large group of illegal immigrants rushed the border during the trip. And the big heat wave, its deadly impact, and a look at when relief is coming.

Here to break it all down, Pollster and Maslansky + Partners President Lee Carter, PwC Partner, Mitch Roschelle, Market Strategist at Third Seven Advisors, Michael Block. Michael, what is the biggest piece of news we're going to get this week that's -- whether it's earnings or even some of the economic data out of the Fed decision next week?

MICHAEL BLOCK, MARKET STRATEGIST, THIRD SEVEN ADVISORS: It call comes down to earnings, you know. First, we have Amazon where we're going to hear -- we may hear more about how prime days went, how the U.S. consumers' doing, and also about how their cloud business is doing after Microsoft and IBM blew expectations in that part of the business last week. Second thing is going to be Facebook and Alphabet. We're going to see how well they're monetizing that data. Like it or not, they keep find new mousetraps to exploit that and do well with it in the ad side.

And then finally, we keep hearing about the U.S. consumer, but there's concerns about the global consumer and two names we haven't mentioned yet, Starbucks and McDonald's going to be reporting the latter part of the week. So, we're going to get a good picture of what U.S. consumers are doing in terms of those businesses, and also how the global growth is looking here as well.

MCDOWELL: And to the point on some of the technology earnings, the top story in The Journal today is that Microsoft, Apple, Amazon, and Facebook have made up almost one-fifth of the S&P's total return this year. But, again, best -- the best return for the S&P since this far end of the year since '98, that's pretty incredible.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNER: And those big, large-cap names are driving it. If you look at the other side of the coin, the small caps are really doing sorry of terribly relative to the large caps. So, the question is, as investors try to sort all this out, are there bargains to be found in the small cap names?

MCDOWELL: Or is the small caps telling us something that people investing in the big cap stocks --

ROSCHELLE: Don't know, yes.

MCDOWELL: -- don't know or ignoring, because, again, if you're in a trade war and a trade fight, you would think that small cap would do better because they're more domestic-oriented, but --

ROSCHELLE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- again, that's not how it's playing out, not year -- not this year.

ROSCHELLE: If it's just four names, we have to ask ourselves, how strong is the underlying trend here?

MCDOWELL: Well said. To our top story this hour as well, the border crisis, Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer making a weekend visit to the border to detail conditions at detention centers. Here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY): Really makes you feel awful. They let us see whatever we wanted to see, but we were told that they tried to make things look better the day before. It's just awful, awful, awful to see how these people are being treated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: President Trump tweeting about the visit last night, saying this, "Senator Chuck Schumer has finally gone to the Southern Border with some Democrat Senators. This is a great thing. Nearby, he missed a large group of illegal immigrants trying to enter the USA illegally. They wildly rushed border patrol. Some agents were badly injured. Based on the comments made by Senator Schumer, he must have seen how dangerous and bad for our country the border is. It is not a manufactured crisis as the fake news media and their Democrat partners tried to portray. He said he wants to meet. I will get up a meeting ASAP."

Joining me now, former Acting ICE Director and former Border Patrol Chief, Ron Vitiello. Ron, good to see you as well. Thanks for being here.

AOC has weighed in. She wants a 9/11-style investigation to figure out how to get rid of the Department of Homeland Security. All of this political stuff, all of it in Washington, D.C., none of it having any serious impact, I don't think, on the stock market. As you just said, Dagen, we're at near to record highs on the three averages. We're going to be up when the market opens this morning.

I think investors just don't care about politics. Same old, same old politics. Where am I going wrong with this? I mean, do you agree with me here? It's all about profits, isn't it? That's what's going to motivate this market surely.

MCDOWELL: Profits. I agree with you 100 percent. And even anecdotally, you drive around this country.

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: The roads are packed. We have the lowest unemployment rate since I was born. You have wages growing even for lower skilled workers, for nonsupervisory workers growing faster than their bosses.

People feel secure in their jobs. They're out driving. They're going to the water park. They're going to visit their uncle's swimming pool. Take a dip over this hot weekend.

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And you know what they're not talking about?

VARNEY: Politics:

MCDOWELL: AOC and the squad, and Robert Mueller. You know what, if they're interested in the Mueller report, they would have read it.

VARNEY: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It's online.

VARNEY: Let's not forget it is summer, it is summer and it's hot and it's sunny, and it's nice out for most of the country. You don't want to be dwelling on racism, and impeachment, and AOC. That's not what Americans are thinking about this summer, but they are going to tune in when that market hits record highs, and when all these wonderful profits come through from these big tech companies. That's what they're looking at, not politics. That's my point.

MCDOWELL: Profitable company means that you work for a company that's in good shape, and workers and investors understand that. Stuart, love you much. Can't wait to see you in less than 10 minutes.

VARNEY: You got it. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Monday through Friday, 9:00 a.m. to noon Eastern Time "Varney & Company."

Coming up, transforming air travel. We take you live to the world's largest air show, Oshkosh and Jeff Flock. Stay with us.

MCDOWELL: It is the largest gathering of aviation enthusiasts. The Experiment Aircraft Association's AirVenture show taking off in Wisconsin. Our own Jeff Flock is in Oshkosh and he will fly with two trained air force fighter pilots coming up.

JEFF FLOCK, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: I should hope so. Have you gotten me there, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: Take it away, my friend.

FLOCK: You do.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

FLOCK: So sorry. That's a T-28 right there, because I got two different headsets on because we're just about to take off with what's called the Wild Blue Rodeo.

LT. COL. JOSH BOUDREAUX, U.S. AIR FORCE THUNDERBIRDS PILOT: That's right.

FLOCK: Josh Boudreaux, Tater they call you.

BOUDREAUX: Yes, sir.

FLOCK: Why they call you Tater?

BOUDREAUX: I can't tell you that.

FLOCK: OK. Very good. Not on live TV anyway. We're going to get -- I'm going to get in this. And look, I got a parachute on. I sincerely hope I don't have to use this parachute, but I did use a parachute as we go ahead and climb in here.

Take a look at what we did last year. We jumped with the Patriot Parachute Team. I jumped out of a perfectly good aircraft, and this one hopefully will be a good aircraft, too.

BOUDREAUX: It would be a great aircraft. It might be your best ride ever.

FLOCK: Wild Blue Rodeo. You do crazy things and what kind of plane are we looking at here?

BOUDREAUX: This is an RV-8A, so about 180 horsepower propeller-driven airplane, pretty light. We're going to go up today. We're going to do loops, rolls, hammerheads and we're doing all kinds of aerobatics and that's why you were in the parachute so we can basically do that.

BOUDREAUX: Got you. Well, let's climb in. We're going to go, and Dagen, we'll be back on the Varney program.

You know, I one time flew with the Thunderbirds, and -- Josh curiously enough was a Thunderbird pilot for many years. And you know what happen when I came back from that trip? It was not pretty. So I think they're hoping for a similar thing but I am not. There you go.

MCDOWELL: Well, Jeff, I flew with the Thunderbirds and I threw up the entire time.

FLOCK: I know you got sick.

MCDOWELL: And then I took a big nap on the Tarmac after I got out of the jet. And so I actually went to sleep on the Tarmac. All these incredible men and women from the Thunderbirds Team standing there lined up, perfectly dressed and I was just taking a little snooze there on the Tarmac. I was sick for about 12 hours after that, but loved every minute of it.

FLOCK: Yes. I sleep for about three days, so you're tough. You can handle it, yes. That's great.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, anybody named Tater Boudreaux is probably a member of my family somewhere down the line. Jeff Flock, thank you, sir.

FLOCK: I don't doubt it.

MCDOWELL: You tell Tater I said that. Still ahead, final thoughts from our all-stars. We'll be right back.

MCDOWELL: Thank you to Michael Block and Mitch Roschelle, but Lee Carter actually gets her own final thoughts because we only have 30 seconds left.

CARTER: Well, I think in this war on messaging, it is more important ever for voters to be vigilant and really focus on the policy issues that matter because it's so easy to get distracted by this cult of personality. Focus on the economy, focus on health care, focus on immigration and really make your decisions based on that because it's so easy to get lost with what's going on here.

urn:contentItem:5VKC-JWK1-DY1J-T40W-00000-00Sen. Cory Booker Promises To Bring America Together. But How?2019-03-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:06ZLexisNexisMorning Edition10:00 AM ESTSteve InskeepCory BookerSen. Cory Booker Promises To Bring America Together. But How?

STEVE INSKEEP: Democratic presidential candidate Cory Booker says he wants to unite a divided nation.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

CORY BOOKER: I love rugged individualism and self-reliance. But rugged individualism didn't get us to the moon. It didn't beat the Nazis or Jim Crow.

STEVE INSKEEP: He says collective action did. Booker is a senator from New Jersey. He's centered his presidential campaign on unity and love. He's the former Democratic mayor of Newark, N.J., who collaborated with former Republican Governor Chris Christie. His presidential announcement video was filled with diverse Americans drumming and playing in marching bands.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

CORY BOOKER: In America, we have a common pain. But what we're lacking is a sense of common purpose.

STEVE INSKEEP: OK. But many politicians say things like that. Who does Booker mean to bring together, and how? We asked when he came by our studios accompanied by a single aide. It is the first of our Opening Arguments - talks with prominent declared presidential contenders.

CORY BOOKER: It wasn't Strom Thurmond that ran to the Senate floor and said one day, it's time for those negro people to have some rights. No, it was blacks and whites, Christians and Jews, Democrats and Republicans who joined in uncommon coalitions of conscience to deal with injustice.

STEVE INSKEEP: So is it not exactly a progressive coalition? It's a coalition of conscience is the phrase that you just used.

CORY BOOKER: You know, these labels that we slap on each other and then dismiss each other because we're - have different labels aren't helping our republic. And I'd like to start talking about shared values and shared ideals.

STEVE INSKEEP: Let me throw a hypothetical voter at you. And I've interviewed voters very much like what I'm going to describe - blue-collar guy, Lordstown, Ohio, just lost his job at a GM plant that is closing, voted once for President Obama but also found President Trump attractive, voted for him once, thinking about it again. Is that guy in your coalition?

CORY BOOKER: That guy needs to - we need to speak to his pain. Our politics need to speak to his pain and be able to address the real concerns he has at the kitchen table. I went out to the Midwest, to the heartland and met with Republicans in Missouri, in Kansas and Nebraska on farms. And one of those families didn't even want me in their home when they researched me on their part of the Internet. They called the person I was - who was showing me around and said, hey. We're a Christian family. We can't have Cory Booker in our home.

STEVE INSKEEP: What made you unpalatable to a Christian family so described?

CORY BOOKER: Whatever they were told by their trusted media - and we all have it. But the friend asked him to come - for me to go see him. I met him at his door. Then we went into his home and found so much common ground because we both agree that the corporate consolidation is killing the independent American family farmer.

STEVE INSKEEP: We should note that plenty of Republicans in the Senate have indicated that they like you. But what happens if it's 2021, you've been elected president the United States? Like President Obama, you try to transcend partisanship. But the political calculation of the moment for Republicans is they need to oppose you on everything. That's the only way they get back in power.

CORY BOOKER: You know, look. If I was going to surrender to cynicism about our nation in that way - I think cynicism is a toxic spiritual state.

STEVE INSKEEP: But I mean, it happened once. What do you do when it happens again?

CORY BOOKER: Yeah. I went to Newark, N.J., at a time that people were so disrespecting, disregarding that city. I mean, it was literally being made fun of by late-night talk show hosts. And people told me, oh, we've tried these things before. It doesn't work. And we got incredibly creative. And at times, I reached out to conservatives I could find coalitions with - Christian evangelicals - not on everything. But I found common ground. And we got things done.

If you go to Newark, N.J., right now, we've gone through our biggest economic development period in 60 years. We have - our schools were just shown to be the No. 1 beat-the-odds school system in America - high poverty, high performance. This is an election. We have a chance to have a revival of civic grace. And we need leaders that are going to be committed to those ideals and dealing with the cause of injustice in our country.

STEVE INSKEEP: Suppose you win the election. Democrats win the Senate. It's a really good 2020 for Democrats. You go out there and push for "Medicare-for-all" - goes to the United States Senate and Republicans feel it's socialism and filibuster it. Do you, at that point, urge Democrats to get rid of the filibuster?

CORY BOOKER: No. I've heard some good arguments since February when people started getting into my face about, we've got to get rid of the filibuster. People on the left feel very strongly about it. I'm willing to listen to more arguments. But we need to understand that there's good reason to have a Senate where we're forced to find pragmatic, bipartisan solutions. Let's be a country that operates from that sense of common purpose.

STEVE INSKEEP: President Bush tried to bring together a consensus on immigration - couldn't get it done. President Obama tried to bring together a consensus on immigration, couldn't get that done, eventually took executive action. President Trump had a very different agenda for immigration, couldn't get his program done either and has just taken executive action. If you're in that same situation as the last three presidents, facing the problems with immigration right now, do you take executive action?

CORY BOOKER: You do what you can on the powers of the presidency allow, and I will do a lot of that. I mean, what's happening with DACA kids - deferred action children, the DREAMers, as they're called, is - violates the values of people on both sides of the aisle. You have President Trump, even rhetorically, saying he supports those children. You do everything you can to affirm the values of our country. And what you don't do is what we see coming from the presidency, which is rank racist rhetoric.

STEVE INSKEEP: Was President Obama's move to, effectively, legalize, for two-year periods, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals people - was that constitutional?

CORY BOOKER: I believe it was constitutional. I believe it was not just constitutional. It reflects common sense.

STEVE INSKEEP: Meaning that if you're president and it hasn't been taken care of yet, you might just flip it right back the way Obama had it.

CORY BOOKER: I will do everything I can to ensure that DACA children, that DREAMers, who are Americans in every way except for a piece of paper - I had a DACA kid that came with me to the State of the Union address a year or two back. She'd started an Internet platform that helped to give employment opportunities to hundreds of people. We're going to deport her. When there's an injustice, people have to understand that often, the opposite of injustice is silence and indifference and apathy.

STEVE INSKEEP: Is Silicon Valley - the firms there, where you have lots of connections. You went to Stanford, which is nearby. Is Silicon Valley part of the coalition you want to bring together behind you?

CORY BOOKER: You know, we need to bring this nation together. It doesn't mean we forgive what I call bad actions or bad actors. We need to make sure that whether it's Silicon Valley or the pharma industry or the big ag, we need to hold people accountable for their actions.

STEVE INSKEEP: Recode, which looks into tech stuff, wrote a long article about you. And they dug up a tweet from 2009. And you, apparently, had had an exciting day in Silicon Valley. Quote, "from green tech to social media, inspiring meetings today. Incredible Silicon Valley leaders who are literally changing, empowering the world." Do you think that's still true?

CORY BOOKER: I mean, I don't know. We're sitting in front of each other, so I'm about to pull out...

STEVE INSKEEP: Looks like an iPhone.

CORY BOOKER: It looks like an iPhone. And, you know, there's a democratization that's going on that technology allows. I've used it in Newark. Let's use just one platform, which is to help people get access to capital. There's so much good that is coming from technology and innovation. At the same time, though, as I lift my phone up again in front of you, do I want one of the big tech firms to be taking my data from me and doing things that are violative of my values?

These are things that are wrong. And so why do we need to universally condemn entire sectors of our society as opposed to talking about what's happening within them that is in violation of our values and creating regulations and rules that make sure that they are affirming what's in the best interest of our country?

STEVE INSKEEP: Senator Booker, thanks so much for coming by.

CORY BOOKER: I appreciate you. Thank you.

(SOUNDBITE OF MARCUS MILLER'S "7-T'S")

Sen. Ted Cruz Press Office

Cruz Press Office: 202-228-7561

Lauren Aronson: laurenaronson@cruz.senate.gov

August 16, 2019

Sen. Cruz: Latest Twitter Bias Underscores Need for Big Tech Transparency

WASHINGTON, D.C. - In the latest example of Big Tech's political bias, Twitter last week continued its pattern of arbitrarily silencing conservative voices when it froze U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's campaign account. From blocking PragerU videos and trailers for the pro-life movie "Unplanned" to blocking political candidates' ads, this move demonstrates once again the enormous control these companies have over our public discourse. It's no wonder a majority of Americans believe tech companies have "too much power and influence" and "intentionally censor political viewpoints they find objectionable."

That's why U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) is working to hold Big Tech accountable to the American people.

As chairman of the Senate Judiciary's Subcommittee on The Constitution and a member of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, Sen. Cruz has chaired and participated in multiple hearings with representatives from Big Tech, including Facebook, Twitter where he addressed concerns over social media bias and censorship. Most recently, Sen. Cruz chaired a hearing entitled: "Google and Censorship through Search Engines," where one witness explained that the bias with which Google curates and disseminates information could have shifted at least 2.6 million votes to Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election.

"Every time we search on Google, we see only the web pages that Google decides we should see, in the order that Google decides we should see them," Sen. Cruz said at the hearing. "This is a staggering amount of power to ban speech, to manipulate search results, to destroy rivals, and to shape culture. More and more Americans are demanding accountability from Big Tech for that massive power."

Here's what news outlets are saying:

Washington Post: Facebook, Google and Twitter under fire from Senate Republicans for censoring conservatives online

"Republicans led by Sen. Ted Cruz on Wednesday pilloried Facebook, Google and Twitter over allegations they censor conservative users and news sites online, threatening federal regulation in response to claims that Democrats long have described as a hoax. The tensions played out early at a Senate hearing where Cruz, the leader of the Judiciary Committee's constitution-focused panel, pointed to reports that he said showed a 'consistent pattern of political bias and censorship on the part of big tech.'"

Daily Signal: Dennis Prager: Google's Suppression of Content Threatens the Future of America

"This statement is as much about what I and PragerU stand for as it is about Google. Those interested in viewing the presentation can do so here. It is an honor to be invited to speak in the United States Senate. But I wish I were not so honored. Because the subject of this hearing--Google and YouTube's (and for that matter, Twitter and Facebook's) suppression of internet content on ideological grounds--threatens the future of America more than any external enemy. In fact, never in American history has there been as strong a threat to freedom of speech as there is today."

The Hill: Juan Williams: We need a backlash against Big Tech

"Another conservative, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), points to the danger Big Tech poses to the 2020 election -- 'The power being amassed by a handful of tech media companies...is a level of power unprecedented in our political discourse," Cruz said at a Washington Post event in June. He is proposing stripping tech platforms of their free speech protections by citing violations of the Communications Decency Act."

Breitbart: Ted Cruz Grills Google on Its Political Bias

"Sen. Cruz said that Google and other social media companies received enhanced legal immunity through Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act with the understanding that they would act as neutral platforms. Cruz explained: A lot of Americans have concerns that big tech media companies and Google in particular, are engaged in political censorship and bias. As you know, Google enjoys a special from liability under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The predicate for that immunity was that Google and other big tech media companies would be neutral public fora."

The following information was released by Texas Senator Ted Cruz:

In the latest example of Big Tech's political bias, Twitter last week continued its pattern of arbitrarily silencing conservative voices when it froze U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's campaign account. From blocking PragerU videos and trailers for the pro-life movie "Unplanned" to blocking political candidates' ads, this move demonstrates once again the enormous control these companies have over our public discourse. It's no wonder a majority of Americans believe tech companies have "too much power and influence" and "intentionally censor political viewpoints they find objectionable."That's why U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) is working to hold Big Tech accountable to the American people.

As chairman of the Senate Judiciary's Subcommittee on The Constitution and a member of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, Sen. Cruz has chaired and participated in multiple hearings with representatives from Big Tech, including Facebook, Twitter and Google where he addressed concerns over social media bias and censorship. Most recently, Sen. Cruz chaired a hearing entitled: "Google and Censorship through Search Engines," where one witness explained that the bias with which Google curates and disseminates information could have shifted at least 2.6 million votes to Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election. "Every time we search on Google, we see only the web pages that Google decides we should see, in the order that Google decides we should see them," Sen. Cruz said at the hearing. "This is a staggering amount of power to ban speech, to manipulate search results, to destroy rivals, and to shape culture. More and more Americans are demanding accountability from Big Tech for that massive power." Here's what news outlets are saying: Washington Post: Facebook, Google and Twitter under fire from Senate Republicans for censoring conservatives online"Republicans led by Sen. Ted Cruz on Wednesday pilloried Facebook, Google and Twitter over allegations they censor conservative users and news sites online, threatening federal regulation in response to claims that Democrats long have described as a hoax. The tensions played out early at a Senate hearing where Cruz, the leader of the Judiciary Committee's constitution-focused panel, pointed to reports that he said showed a 'consistent pattern of political bias and censorship on the part of big tech.'" Daily Signal: Dennis Prager: Google's Suppression of Content Threatens the Future of America"This statement is as much about what I and PragerU stand for as it is about Google. Those interested in viewing the presentation can do so here. It is an honor to be invited to speak in the United States Senate. But I wish I were not so honored. Because the subject of this hearing-Google and YouTube's (and for that matter, Twitter and Facebook's) suppression of internet content on ideological grounds-threatens the future of America more than any external enemy. In fact, never in American history has there been as strong a threat to freedom of speech as there is today." The Hill: Juan Williams: We need a backlash against Big Tech"Another conservative, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), points to the danger Big Tech poses to the 2020 election - 'The power being amassed by a handful of tech media companies...is a level of power unprecedented in our political discourse," Cruz said at a Washington Post event in June. He is proposing stripping tech platforms of their free speech protections by citing violations of the Communications Decency Act." Breitbart: Ted Cruz Grills Google on Its Political Bias"Sen. Cruz said that Google and other social media companies received enhanced legal immunity through Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act with the understanding that they would act as neutral platforms. Cruz explained: A lot of Americans have concerns that big tech media companies and Google in particular, are engaged in political censorship and bias. As you know, Google enjoys a special from liability under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The predicate for that immunity was that Google and other big tech media companies would be neutral public fora." CLICK HERE to watch Sen. Cruz on "Fox News @ Night with Shannon Bream." CLICK HERE to watch Sen. Cruz' QandA with Tony Romm, Senior Technology Reporter at the Washington Post, at the 3rd annual "Free to State Summit." CLICK HERE to watch Sen. Cruz on "Fox and Friends."

Cruz, Ted - (R - TX) News Release2019-08-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:06ZLexisNexisU.S. SENATE DOCUMENTSSen. Cruz: Latest Twitter Bias Underscores Need for Big Tech TransparencySen. Cruz, Ted - (R - TX) News Release

WASHINGTON, D.C. - In the latest example of Big Tech's political bias, Twitter last week continued its pattern of arbitrarily silencing conservative voices when it froze U.S. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's campaign account. From blocking PragerU videos and trailers for the pro-life movie "Unplanned" to blocking political candidates' ads, this move demonstrates once again the enormous control these companies have over our public discourse. It's no wonder a majority of Americans believe tech companies have "too much power and influence" and "intentionally censor political viewpoints they find objectionable."

That's why U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) is working to hold Big Tech accountable to the American people.

As chairman of the Senate Judiciary's Subcommittee on The Constitution and a member of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation, Sen. Cruz has chaired and participated in multiple hearings with representatives from Big Tech, including Facebook, Twitter and Google where he addressed concerns over social media bias and censorship. Most recently, Sen. Cruz chaired a hearing entitled: "Google and Censorship through Search Engines," where one witness explained that the bias with which Google curates and disseminates information could have shifted at least 2.6 million votes to Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election.

"Every time we search on Google, we see only the web pages that Google decides we should see, in the order that Google decides we should see them," Sen. Cruz said at the hearing. "This is a staggering amount of power to ban speech, to manipulate search results, to destroy rivals, and to shape culture. More and more Americans are demanding accountability from Big Tech for that massive power."

Here's what news outlets are saying:

Washington Post: Facebook, Google and Twitter under fire from Senate Republicans for censoring conservatives online

"Republicans led by Sen. Ted Cruz on Wednesday pilloried Facebook, Google and Twitter over allegations they censor conservative users and news sites online, threatening federal regulation in response to claims that Democrats long have described as a hoax. The tensions played out early at a Senate hearing where Cruz, the leader of the Judiciary Committee's constitution-focused panel, pointed to reports that he said showed a 'consistent pattern of political bias and censorship on the part of big tech.'"

Daily Signal: Dennis Prager: Google's Suppression of Content Threatens the Future of America

"This statement is as much about what I and PragerU stand for as it is about Google. Those interested in viewing the presentation can do so here. It is an honor to be invited to speak in the United States Senate. But I wish I were not so honored. Because the subject of this hearing-Google and YouTube's (and for that matter, Twitter and Facebook's) suppression of internet content on ideological grounds-threatens the future of America more than any external enemy. In fact, never in American history has there been as strong a threat to freedom of speech as there is today."

The Hill: Juan Williams: We need a backlash against Big Tech

"Another conservative, Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), points to the danger Big Tech poses to the 2020 election - 'The power being amassed by a handful of tech media companies...is a level of power unprecedented in our political discourse," Cruz said at a Washington Post event in June. He is proposing stripping tech platforms of their free speech protections by citing violations of the Communications Decency Act."

Breitbart: Ted Cruz Grills Google on Its Political Bias

"Sen. Cruz said that Google and other social media companies received enhanced legal immunity through Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act with the understanding that they would act as neutral platforms. Cruz explained: A lot of Americans have concerns that big tech media companies and Google in particular, are engaged in political censorship and bias. As you know, Google enjoys a special from liability under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. The predicate for that immunity was that Google and other big tech media companies would be neutral public fora."

Go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mh7kz0_nV40 to watch Sen. Cruz on "Fox News @ Night with Shannon Bream."

Go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bpAheMURwS4andfeature=youtu.be to watch Sen. Cruz' QandA with Tony Romm, Senior Technology Reporter at the Washington Post, at the 3rd annual "Free to State Summit."

Go to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U3KKaGlgfZQandfeature=youtu.be to watch Sen. Cruz on "Fox and Friends."

Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, issued the following news release:

* * *

- Discusses Google and Big Tech censorship hearing on The Michael Berry Show

* * *

U.S. Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas) chairman of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary's Subcommittee on The Constitution, this week went on The Michael Berry Show to discuss his recent hearing investigating Google's pattern of political bias and censorship.

"The pattern of political bias from YouTube, from Google is massive," Sen. Cruz said. "And I'll tell you Michael, the most stunning testimony was from a psychologist Dr. Epstein, who is not a Republican. He is by his own description a Democrat, a liberal. He was a Hillary Clinton supporter. And he concluded that Google's biased search results swung a minimum of 2.6 million votes to Hillary Clinton in 2016. His testimony in particular was stunning, and I encourage everyone listening to go and watch, and listen to his testimony, because he also said that if it's not addressed, that in 2020 as many as 15 million votes could be swung by Google, and Facebook, and Twitter, and their deceptive censorship online."

Sen. Cruz's interview may be found here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0GPmIA-QzPk&

Several news outlets covered Sen. Cruz's subcommittee hearing. Press coverage may be viewed below.

Breitbart: Ted Cruz Grills Google VP on Breitbart 'Good Censor' Scoop

"Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) held Google's feet to the fire on its murky legal status earlier today, using information from Breitbart News' exclusive publication of "The Good Censor," a leaked internal briefing from Google, to support his line of questioning. Sen. Cruz sent a copy of The Good Censor, which Breitbart News exclusively published last October, to Google ahead of the hearing, where a representative of the tech giant admitted his company had produced the document. The Senator highlighted 'tech firms are performing a balancing act between two incompatible positions. On the one side, create an 'Unmediated market of ideas - 100% commit to the American tradition that prioritizes free speech for democracy, not civility, by creating spaces where all values including civility norms are always open to debate.' That's on the one side, according to Google's own assessment. On the other side is 'create well-ordered spaces for safety and civility - 100% commit to the European tradition, which favors dignity over liberty and civility over freedom, by censoring - and I will note, this is Google's word, censoring - racial and religious hatred even when there's no provocation to violence."

KFOX: (VIDEO) Cruz on Tech Censorship

"Google is finding itself on Capitol Hill talking about censorship and search engines. The company is among other top social media companies being accused of conservative bias and the focus of lawmakers to figure out whether or how these companies should be regulated. Republican Senator Ted Cruz shared this at the hearing: 'As we have heard time and time again the big defense by Big Tech is, it wasn't me, the algorithm did it.' While issues on the reach of these companies are bipartisan some Democrats disagree with the political bias. 'Study after study has debunked the suggestion of political bias on the part of Facebook, Google, and Twitter.' This hearing comes after several similar hearings in Washington and comes on the heels of conservative groups calling attention to what they say is proof of bias."

KTRH: Cruz has Google in his sights

"Texas Senator Ted Cruz has Big Tech in his sights once again. Back in April, Cruz led a hearing about how conservatives are treated by Facebook and Twitter. Now he's going after Google. Cruz led another hearing about Google and what they do to conservatives this week. He told Fox News that Google (which owns YouTube) is a monopoly that abuses its power. 'Google is a monopoly. Google may well be the most powerful company on the face of the planet because they have a monopoly on information, on what you know and what I know. And not only that, but Google owns YouTube, which is the second most popular website on the face of the planet. And the problem is, they use monopoly powers to silence voices they don't like.'"

Washington Examiner: Ted Cruz: Google has 'a staggering amount of power' to shape culture

"'This is a staggering amount of power to ban speech, manipulate search results, destroy rivals, and shape culture,' Cruz said. Cruz's statement also referred to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, which gives tech companies legal immunity from the content that is published on their platforms He said that tech companies get a perk or subsidy thanks to the law, but that implicit in that law was an agreement from companies like Google that they wouldn't discriminate based on political viewpoint. Cruz said that, when that law was written, it was done so under the assumption that 'There wouldn't be a conservative internet and a liberal internet: just the internet,' but that bargain is falling apart. 'The American people are instead subject to both overt censorship and covert manipulation,' Cruz said. "If Big Tech cannot provide us with evidence that it's not playing Big Brother with its immense powers, we don't need to give them a subsidy through Section 230."

Google may well be the most powerful company on the face of the planet because they have a monopoly on information, on what you know and what I know.' Cruz appeared on 'Fox and Friends' listing ways he would look to tackle censorship of social media, which conservatives say platforms like Facebook and Twitter are blocking their views. He noted not that accounts are being deleted, but that their posts are being hidden from followers by algorithms under the guise of preventing hate speech. 'What's happening is the social media sites are censoring, they're shadow banning. If they don't like what you're saying, they just hide what you're saying. That is essentially a fraud on the consumer, and they're deceiving the consumer because they've got a political agenda.'"

Washington Times: Google executive refuses to commit to independent audit during Senate hearing

"The hearing, marked by fiery exchanges between combative lawmakers and the evasive executive, began with a gotcha moment: Chairman Ted Cruz unveiled an internal Google document titled, 'The Good Censor: How Can Google Reassure the World that It Protects Users from Harmful Content While Supporting Free Speech?' The March 2018 document said tech companies are performing a 'balancing act between two incompatible positions,' namely 'an unmediated marketplace of ideas 100 percent commit to the American tradition that prioritizes free speech' and "well-ordered spaces for safety and civility 100 percent commit to the European tradition that favors dignity over liberty.' Mr. Cruz said that the European model had won out on social media platforms, according to the document, which said, 'Tech firms have gradually shifted away from unmediated free speech and toward censorship and moderation.'"

Wall Street Journal: Tech Giants Draw Fire in Congress

"At a Senate hearing on alleged censorship, Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas) accused Google of 'playing Big Brother' by collecting swaths of data on Americans who use its search engines and controlling public discourse through its dominance of internet search. Mr. Cruz said the tech giant's frequent response-that its results are produced by algorithms-is inadequate. Algorithms are 'written and maintained by people,' he said. Karan Bhatia, Google's vice president of global government affairs and public policy, told Mr. Cruz the company has built platforms that operate in an apolitical way."

KVII: Google, censorship and accusations of political bias

"Republican Senator Ted Cruz of Texas chaired the hearing. 'As we've heard time and time again, Big Tech's favorite defense is 'It wasn't me, the algorithm did it',' said Sen. Ted Cruz R-Tex., Chair of the Subcommittee on the Constitution. 'Google's search engine isn't controlled by a supernatural voice, it's maintained by people.'"

Cruz led another hearing about Google and what they do to conservatives this week. He told Fox News that Google (which owns YouTube) is a monopoly that abuses its power. 'Google is a monopoly. Google may well be the most powerful company on the face of the planet because they have a monopoly on information, on what you know and what I know. And not only that, but Google owns YouTube, which is the second most popular website on the face of the planet. And the problem is, they use monopoly powers to silence voices they don't like.'"

Washington Examiner: Ted Cruz: Google has 'a staggering amount of power' to shape culture

"'This is a staggering amount of power to ban speech, manipulate search results, destroy rivals, and shape culture,' Cruz said. Cruz's statement also referred to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act of 1996, which gives tech companies legal immunity from the content that is published on their platforms He said that tech companies get a perk or subsidy thanks to the law, but that implicit in that law was an agreement from companies like Google that they wouldn't discriminate based on political viewpoint. Cruz said that, when that law was written, it was done so under the assumption that 'There wouldn't be a conservative internet and a liberal internet: just the internet,' but that bargain is falling apart. 'The American people are instead subject to both overt censorship and covert manipulation,' Cruz said. "If Big Tech cannot provide us with evidence that it's not playing Big Brother with its immense powers, we don't need to give them a subsidy through Section 230."

KETK: Cruz calls Google a 'monopoly', criticizes social media for censorship

"Sen. Ted Cruz hurled criticism at Google while previewing a Senate hearing he would chair on Tuesday dealing with censorship by social media. 'Google is a monopoly. Google may well be the most powerful company on the face of the planet because they have a monopoly on information, on what you know and what I know.' Cruz appeared on 'Fox and Friends' listing ways he would look to tackle censorship of social media, which conservatives say platforms like Facebook and Twitter are blocking their views. He noted not that accounts are being deleted, but that their posts are being hidden from followers by algorithms under the guise of preventing hate speech. 'What's happening is the social media sites are censoring, they're shadow banning. If they don't like what you're saying, they just hide what you're saying. That is essentially a fraud on the consumer, and they're deceiving the consumer because they've got a political agenda.'"

Washington Times: Google executive refuses to commit to independent audit during Senate hearing

"The hearing, marked by fiery exchanges between combative lawmakers and the evasive executive, began with a gotcha moment: Chairman Ted Cruz unveiled an internal Google document titled, 'The Good Censor: How Can Google Reassure the World that It Protects Users from Harmful Content While Supporting Free Speech?' The March 2018 document said tech companies are performing a 'balancing act between two incompatible positions,' namely 'an unmediated marketplace of ideas 100 percent commit to the American tradition that prioritizes free speech' and "well-ordered spaces for safety and civility 100 percent commit to the European tradition that favors dignity over liberty.' Mr. Cruz said that the European model had won out on social media platforms, according to the document, which said, 'Tech firms have gradually shifted away from unmediated free speech and toward censorship and moderation.'"

Wall Street Journal: Tech Giants Draw Fire in Congress

"At a Senate hearing on alleged censorship, Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas) accused Google of 'playing Big Brother' by collecting swaths of data on Americans who use its search engines and controlling public discourse through its dominance of internet search. Mr. Cruz said the tech giant's frequent response-that its results are produced by algorithms-is inadequate. Algorithms are 'written and maintained by people,' he said. Karan Bhatia, Google's vice president of global government affairs and public policy, told Mr. Cruz the company has built platforms that operate in an apolitical way."

KVII: Google, censorship and accusations of political bias

"Republican Senator Ted Cruz of Texas chaired the hearing. 'As we've heard time and time again, Big Tech's favorite defense is 'It wasn't me, the algorithm did it',' said Sen. Ted Cruz R-Tex., Chair of the Subcommittee on the Constitution. 'Google's search engine isn't controlled by a supernatural voice, it's maintained by people.'"

David Perdue (R-GA) Is Interviewed About the China Trade Conversation; Media: China to Increase Import of Agricultural Goods; Turkey Holding Back on Incursion with Russia's Help; Senate Democrats Want SALT Deduction Cap Overturned; Boeing Cutting Production of 787 Dreamliner To 12 Aircraft/Year Starting In Late 2020; Extradition Bill Killed, China May Replace Carrie Lam; Disney CEO: Speaking About Protests Will Harm Business; Mr. Zuckerberg Goes To Washington; Ripple Opening D.C. David Perdue (R-GA) Is Interviewed About the China Trade Conversation; Media: China to Increase Import of Agricultural Goods; Turkey Holding Back on Incursion with Russia's Help; Senate Democrats Want SALT Deduction Cap Overturned; Boeing Cutting Production of 787 Dreamliner To 12 Aircraft/Year Starting In Late 2020; Extradition Bill Killed, China May Replace Carrie Lam; Disney CEO: Speaking About Protests Will Harm Business; Mr. Zuckerberg Goes To Washington; Ripple Opening D.C. OfficeMaria Bartiromo, Cheryl Casone, Dagen McDowell, Charles Payne, Gerri Willis

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, October 23rd. Your top stories right now, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Earnings in focus, driving markets this morning. Boeing missed expectations. However, the aerospace giant said that it is making steady progress, getting the 737 Max back in service, looking for its return in the fourth quarter. The revenue was actually better-than-expected, and the stock is up now, it had been lower earlier.

Caterpillar, meanwhile, under pressure this morning, after missing estimates and cutting its full year earnings guidance. Here too, though, the stock is way off of the lows of the morning, down just two-thirds of one percent now.

Futures right now indicate a lower opening for the broader averages, but again, off of the lows of the morning. The Dow Industrials down 44 points, the S&P is down five, and the NASDAQ lower by six. Yesterday, earnings and uncertainty over the timing of the U.K.'s exit from the E.U., weighed on markets. Still, the S&P 500 is just one percent away from its all-time record close.

Global markets this morning, look like this, European indices are mixed, you got the FT-100 up 14 points, there are growing concerns over Hong Kong, however. The CAC Quarante in Paris is down 34 and the DAX Index is lower by 6.

Let's check the Asian markets with the concerns over Hong Kong, put pressure on markets in Asia, overnight. And as you can see, the Shanghai Composite down half a percent, Hang Seng down almost one percent. Japan was up, with the Nikkei Average up just a fraction, pushing it to a one- year high.

Fallout in Hong Kong, the controversial extradition bill that sparked the whole protests, in the first place, has been formally withdrawn 20 weeks later. Reports now say that China is looking into replacing leader, Carrie Lam.

Mark Zuckerberg is on the hot seat this morning, in Washington. The Facebook CEO is testifying to defend his proposed cryptocurrency on Capitol Hill. We are taking a look at what to expect there, coming up.

All those stories coming up this Wednesday morning, and joining me to break it all down, FOX Business' Dagen McDowell, National Securities Corporation chief market strategist, Art Hogan, and Farvahar Partners founder and CEO, Omeed Malik. It's been a great show, guys.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: So much news.

BARTIROMO: Yes, in terms of earnings. And I'm very -- I'm impressed by some of these stock performances, because we are well off of the lows even when you look at a company like Caterpillar, which is indicating a glowing slowdown, globally.

ART HOGAN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, NATIONAL SECURITIES CORPORATION: Yes, and I think Dagen really nailed that at the outside, as soon as they reported. Hey, let's look how the company has done over the last 12 months, is certainly a year-to-date basis, up only eight percent. S&P 500 up 20 percent.

So, a lot of this bad news is priced in. I think the market is able to, sort of, walk on by and not get too upset about it, but at least Caterpillar's today.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and that's our top story because Caterpillar is an indicator of global growth, it is well off of the lows, after cutting its full-year guidance. Gerri Willis is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange this morning, taking a look at that, and the broader averages, even the broader markets, Gerri, off of the lows.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK REPORTER: Well, you know, here is what you are going to see, I mean, this is going to follow Boeing, it's going to follow Caterpillar. I'm talking about Caterpillar today, a disappointment on the top and the bottom line. Earnings coming in at 2.66 a share, as you've been reporting. Revenues also a disappointment.

They also lowered their earnings outlook, so kind of a trifecta of bad news for the stock. I want to tell you what the CEO Jim Umpleby had to say about what went wrongly here. He says, our volumes declined as dealers reduced their inventories and end user demand while positive was lower than our expectations.

So, the orders for their products not coming in as expected, and this stock has seen -- as really a barometer of what's going on with China, the China business.

Now, you might have noticed the stock momentarily turned positive, just moments ago. It's back in the negative column. I think traders saw this headline. Caterpillar Inc. says, tariff's impact for 2019 would be below its previous guidance of 250 million and 350 million. So, a ray of sunshine, deep in that report, but very small. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Gerri, thank you so much. Gerri Willis on Wall Street this morning. We want to look at China trade. Chinese state television is reporting that China will increase the import of goods, like agriculture and consumer products to stabilize foreign trade.

The country also keeping the Yuan exchange rate, stable. These are all issues that were talked about between the U.S. and China, as top Chinese trade officials strike an optimistic tone over talks in Washington.

Joining us right now is Georgia senator, member of the Senate Budget Banking and Armed Services Committees, David Perdue. Senator, it's good to see you this morning, thanks so much for joining us.

SEN. DAVID PERDUE (R-GA): Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Lot of mixed headlines out of China. Certainly, you got the country bullying American companies, to do it their way, including the NBA, and then you've got them promising to buy more agricultural products. How do you see this China trade conversation?

PERDUE: Well, having lived over there and worked over there, most of my career, Maria, I think this latest development is terribly encouraging. It's a very small step. We can take our ag exports from 9 billion to something like 40 or 50 billion.

But more importantly, it's an incremental step, which heretofore neither side really wanted to do. So, I think this latest round of agreement is extremely encouraging. I was just over in China, over Labor Day, with Steve Daines, a senator from Montana. And we had meetings with Liu He, their trade representative.

And we were encouraged then that they gave us indications that they were willing to begin doing this. So, I think this bodes well for our next conversation, really, to the next potential hike in tariffs for December.

BARTIROMO: Do you have any indication that China is going to stop stealing intellectual property from the United States?

PERDUE: You know, Maria, that's the question, I mean, there are five things we're trying to do in these trade talks, and they're not all related to trade, some of them are related to national security. We want them to stop stealing our technology, stop forcing the transfer of technology into the joint ventures, comply with the WTO, stop the cyber war, and give us equal access.

So, the WTO compliance in equal access, is sort of our first step. Equal access is the easy part. The encouragement I have is that by making an incremental agreement now, it gives us hope that we can begin to increment our way toward the ultimate solution here.

BARTIROMO: So, it sounds like you don't have any indications that they're going to stop stealing yet.

PERDUE: No, I mean --

BARTIROMO: OK.

PERDUE: First of all, they'd have to deny that they've ever done that.

BARTIROMO: Right. I know they don't even admit it.

PERDUE: And so, this continues --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

PERDUE: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: We want to switch gears, ask you about the Middle East tensions, Turkey signaling that it will hold back, on the incursion into Syria, as Russian President, Vladimir Putin, agrees to help Turkey drive out Kurdish fighters from buffer zones in Syria.

This is happening just one day after the 120-hour ceasefire between Turkey and Syria, expired. Does it concern you that Russia and Turkey are partnering here?

PERDUE: I'm very concerned, Maria, that a member of NATO, Turkey, is partnering with Russia. I mean, NATO was created in order to stand up against the threat from the Soviet Union, and now Russia. And so, what Putin has done is stepped into a vacuum.

What Erdogan wanted all along was a 30-mile buffer there, between Turkey and Syria, right on the border, I've been there, and it's a reasonable request. Now, he's not good guy, but there are three allies that we were working with, to develop that. It didn't happen in the timeframe that everybody thought it would.

And so, Turkey stepped in, and now Putin has stepped into that vacuum. So, I'm very troubled by that. I don't think this changes our mission in Syria. Though, that is to make sure that ISIS does not get redeveloped, that we give a counter to Iran, and that we continue to protect Iraq. What's most troubling is how Iraq is responding to the movement of troops right now, in and out of Syria --

BARTIROMO: Yes, they don't --

PERDUE: -- between Iraq and Syria.

BARTIROMO: Yes, they don't -- they don't want their troops there. Omeed - -

OMEED MALIK, FOUNDER AND CEO, FARVAHAR PARTNERS: Yes. Hi, Senator, Omeed Malik, proud Emory Law School alum, so a lot of love for Atlanta. I want to ask you about Syria, I've been a bit shocked about how simplistic the analysis has been, though.

As you pointed out, rightfully, Turkey is a NATO ally, and they have housed over 3 million Syrian refugees within their borders, that they didn't ask for, that they've had to burden.

So, having them go back and help them repatriate them into Syria. And the Turkish government is no friend of Assad, and having their influence there, potentially, counterweight the Iranian influence as a NATO ally, could actually be thought of as a beneficial posture, which I know the President says.

So, I don't think that perspective has received enough airtime, and I do think it's one that presumably you started to allude to, that you may agree with slightly.

PERDUE: Well, it's an unholy alliance to think about Bashar al-Assad partnering with Erdogan, they hate each other right now. Putin seems to be the peacemaker. All of a sudden, it puts us on the side of Iran with regard to that triumvirate.

So, it's a very confused calculus. But here's the bottom line, you said it best, the real motivating factor here are the refugees up in Syria, some 3 million. I've been to Gaziantep, we've seen them, but most of those refugees were assimilated into the cities in Turkey. You can imagine what pressure that is putting on them.

And rightly so, all the allies should have really moved faster, I think, to support this buffer zone, to move those refugees back into Syria.

MCDOWELL: Does NATO have -- Senator, does NATO have a role in doing that, and protecting the Kurds in northern part of Syria, but also, moving -- caring for and taking care of those refugees?

PERDUE: Well, the number one thing is that the Kurds have partnered with us to defeat ISIS. We've removed their caliphate, the remnants are still there, though, and we're going to keep a force of Special Operation officers there.

We are now today, partnering with the Kurds, in Northern Syria, but this has not been determined yet what the role is going to be of Erdogan, and I think that's the real crucial calculus here, is who is going to maintain and measure and manage that buffer zone?

Right now, Erdogan steps into a vacuum. I think it's still --I'm still hopeful that we can have an ally opposed to that. Putin is only patrolling six miles, don't -- I mean, this is not that he's taken over the buffer zone. But if nothing happens from the (INAUDIBLE) he could well do that.

BARTIROMO: Let me switch gears, ask you about some domestic issues, Senator, because the Democrats are looking to force a vote today, to overturn the state and local tax deduction, SALT, it's capped now at $10,000. Minority leader Chuck Schumer says overturning it would, quote, put power back in the hands of homeowners. Your reaction?

PERDUE: It's the most hypocritical thing I've read, you know, in the last few months up here, just when you think that they can't be any more hypocritical, they come up with something like this. Absolutely ridiculous. This would be a tax cut for absolutely the top earners in New York, California, Illinois, with a high tax state.

And look, Maria, the rest of the country has been subsidizing these high tax states, forever. What we did two years ago was balance that across the country. This -- the regulatory work we did and this tax bill we've passed in '17, absolutely is currently the best economic turnaround in U.S. history.

But what Schumer wants to do is go back and give money back now, to the richest in his state. That's the most hypocritical thing I have ever heard.

BARTIROMO: Have you seen any indication from some of these local mayors and governors, and of the high tax states, that they are going to change their tax policy and cut taxes and reign in spending, as a result of what they're seeing the impact of SALT deduction going away is?

PERDUE: Well, to a reasonable person, that would be the first thing you would go to, wouldn't it, Maria? I mean, that's what we were hoping that was going to happen.

BARTIROMO: Right. I know that.

PERDUE: We can't keep -- we can't keep subsidizing these high-stake tax states. And look, the benefits that the people in those states are supposed to get from those high taxes are not there either. I mean, we can pay low tax states to high tax states, it's not there.

But, again, the hypocrisy of going back and giving that tax break to the richest in those states, is so counter strategy from what they say they believe in, and I just think this is hypocritical. This is not going to go anywhere in the Senate, I can assure you.

BARTIROMO: Senator, it's good to see you this morning, thanks so much.

PERDUE: Thanks guys.

BARTIROMO: Senator David Perdue joining us. Joining the conversation this morning, the founder and chief investment officer of Hayman Capital Management is here, Kyle Bass, going to weigh in on investing today and what's happening in Hong Kong. Plus, U.S. Energy Secretary Rick Perry joins us. Lot to talk about with Rick Perry, so stay with us for that.

First, though, a big miss for Boeing, the aerospace giant missed expectations, but says the 737 Max jet is on track to return to the skies, before the end of the year. Then, the Hong Kong story, crisis continuing there. It is officially now withdrawing the controversial extradition bill, as Beijing is reportedly looking to oust the Hong Kong leader, Carrie Lam. All the details after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Among the big stories in earnings this morning, Boeing, the aerospace company, reporting disappointing earnings but revenue above expectations. The stock is up now one percent after the company said that the 737 Max aircraft will resume service during the fourth-quarter. Joining us right now by telephone is Melius Research founding partner and global aerospace and defense analyst Carter Copeland. Carter, good to have you on the program this morning. Your reaction to the Boeing quarter?

CARTER COPELAND, FOUNDING PARTNER & GLOBAL AEROSPACE AND DEFENSE ANALYST, MELIUS RESEARCH: Yes, look, I mean, a lot of this is not about the numbers. We know they're going to be messy as a result of the Max crisis. But what people are looking at is the timeline, first and foremost, of the 737 and the return to service which, in the company, it's sort of sticking their guns, at least, in rough terms here, trying to get the plane back into service in Q4, as opposed to last quarter, they hoped for early Q4. So, a slight slippage there, but I think a lot of people were very fearful that the company would announce a production cut, and you didn't get that.

But elsewhere in the portfolio, you know, you're seeing good performance. They announced that they're going to cut the triple seven rate for a temporary -- or excuse me, the 787 rate for a temporary period of time. I think that's completely related to China, and getting a trade deal done there. But even despite that, the financial performance on that program was quite strong. So, I think what people are looking at is, OK, once you get past the Max and you get to a period of normalization, what will you find? And if we're not getting incremental charges, and we are seeing good performance elsewhere in a portfolio, that points to a normalized number beyond the crisis that people can be, I think, somewhat helpful on.

HOGAN: Carter, when you think about the getting me on this 737 Max, and the company's guidance of hopefully getting out there in the first quarter. Is that -- does that seem like that's a doable projection? And the second thing is we saw an executive leave yesterday. Is this the first of many, or do you think that's it now, we've (INAUDIBLE) people have had to leave to start putting this behind them?

COPELAND: Well, it's tough. On the -- on the leadership change stuff, you know, it's tough to say. I think what -- we were kind of as a view, we wouldn't see much change until the plane returned to the sky because you don't want disruption internally, while, you know, you try to get over, you know, a big challenge like that.

But in general, you know, the CEO of Boeing Commercial Kevin McAllister leaving, I think the market will take that in stride, in part because they saw McAllister as the biggest proponent of launching a new plane called the NMA. And so, I think the general view will be that change in leadership will lower the probability of a plane that I think most think is not going to be a big moneymaker. So, you know, whether we'll see more leadership change, I think is a bit up in the air. You know, whether or not they can get the plane you know, back into the sky in in rough terms along with their schedule is, is a tough question to ask. I think from a -- or tough question to answer.

I think from a technical standpoint, they're looking at the black and white sort of ins and outs of, you know, engineering evaluation and saying, Yes, this is -- and these are technical requirements that we think we can meet. But when you layer on political uncertainty, and, you know, the sort of all the implications that come along with that, it introduces a level of uncertainty that that I think, you know, they have to deal with, and that's really what makes the question tough to answer.
